Docs.param: A containing a Java Native Interface (JNI) object reference.
Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of JNI objects; called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a Java Native Interface object.
The constructor will initializes the property of the new instance using and .

Docs.summary: A broadcast intent which can be fired to the component specified in the meta-data defined in the meta-data of an satisfying .

remarks.para: A broadcast intent which can be fired to the component specified in the meta-data defined in the meta-data of an satisfying .
When fired with , a of extras will be returned to the provided result receiver, and should ideally contain values for and .
(Whether these are actually provided is up to the particular implementation. It is recommended that s implementing provide this information, but it is not required.)

Docs.summary: Starts an activity that will prompt the user for speech and send it through a speech recognizer.

remarks.para: Starts an activity that will prompt the user for speech and send it through a speech recognizer. The results will be returned via activity results (in , if you start the intent using ), or forwarded via a PendingIntent if one is provided.
Starting this intent with just is not supported. You must either use , or provide a PendingIntent, to receive recognition results.
The implementation of this API is likely to stream audio to remote servers to perform speech recognition which can use a substantial amount of bandwidth.
Required extras:
Optional extras:
Result extras (returned in the result, not to be specified in the request):
NOTE: There may not be any applications installed to handle this action, so you should make sure to catch .

Docs.summary: Starts an activity that will prompt the user for speech without requiring the user's visual attention or touch input.

remarks.para:
Starts an activity that will prompt the user for speech without requiring the user's visual attention or touch input. It will send it through a speech recognizer, and either synthesize speech for a web search result or trigger another type of action based on the user's speech.
This activity may be launched while device is locked in a secure mode. Special care must be taken to ensure that the voice actions that are performed while hands free cannot compromise the device's security. The activity should check the value of the extra to determine whether the device has been securely locked. If so, the activity should either restrict the set of voice actions that are permitted or require some form of secure authentication before proceeding.
To ensure that the activity's user interface is visible while the lock screen is showing, the activity should set the window flag. Otherwise the activity's user interface may be hidden by the lock screen. The activity should take care not to leak private information when the device is securely locked.
Optional extras:

Docs.summary: Starts an activity that will prompt the user for speech, send it through a speech recognizer, and either display a web search result or trigger another type of action based on the user's speech.

remarks.para: Starts an activity that will prompt the user for speech, send it through a speech recognizer, and either display a web search result or trigger another type of action based on the user's speech.
If you want to avoid triggering any type of action besides web search, you can use the extra.
Required extras:
Optional extras:

Result extras (returned in the result, not to be specified in the request):
(optional)
NOTE: There may not be any applications installed to handle this action, so you should make sure to catch .

Docs.summary: Meta-data name under which an implementing can use to expose the class name of a which can respond to request for more information, from any of the broadcast intents specified in this class.

remarks.para: Meta-data name under which an implementing can use to expose the class name of a which can respond to request for more information, from any of the broadcast intents specified in this class.

Broadcast intents can be directed to the class name specified in the meta-data by creating an , setting the component with , and using
with another which can receive the results.
The method is provided as a convenience to create a broadcast intent based on the value of this meta-data, if available.
This is optional and not all s which implement are required to implement this. Thus retrieving this meta-data may be null.

Docs.summary: The extra key used in an intent to the speech recognizer for voice search.

remarks.para: The extra key used in an intent to the speech recognizer for voice search. Not generally to be used by developers. The system search dialog uses this, for example, to set a calling package for identification by a voice search API. If this extra is set by anyone but the system process, it should be overridden by the voice search implementation.

Docs.summary: A float array of confidence scores of the recognition results when performing .

remarks.para: A float array of confidence scores of the recognition results when performing . The array should be the same size as the ArrayList returned in , and should contain values ranging from 0.0 to 1.0, or -1 to represent an unavailable confidence score.
Confidence values close to 1.0 indicate high confidence (the speech recognizer is confident that the recognition result is correct), while values close to 0.0 indicate low confidence.
Returned in the results; not to be specified in the recognition request. This extra is optional and might not be provided. Only present when is returned in an activity result.

Docs.summary: Optional IETF language tag (as defined by BCP 47), for example "en-US".

remarks.para: Optional IETF language tag (as defined by BCP 47), for example "en-US". This tag informs the recognizer to perform speech recognition in a language different than the one set in the .

Docs.summary: Informs the recognizer which speech model to prefer when performing .

remarks.para: Informs the recognizer which speech model to prefer when performing . The recognizer uses this information to fine tune the results. This extra is required. Activities implementing may interpret the values as they see fit.

Docs.summary: The key to the extra in the returned by which is a that represents the current language preference this user has specified - a locale string like "en-US".

remarks.para: The key to the extra in the returned by which is a that represents the current language preference this user has specified - a locale string like "en-US".

Docs.summary: Optional limit on the maximum number of results to return.

remarks.para: Optional limit on the maximum number of results to return. If omitted the recognizer will choose how many results to return. Must be an integer.

Docs.summary: Specify this boolean extra in a broadcast of to indicate that only the current language preference is needed in the response.

remarks.para: Specify this boolean extra in a broadcast of to indicate that only the current language preference is needed in the response. This avoids any additional computation if all you need is in the response.

Docs.summary: Optional value which can be used to indicate the referer url of a page in which speech was requested.

remarks.para: Optional value which can be used to indicate the referer url of a page in which speech was requested. For example, a web browser may choose to provide this for uses of speech on a given page.

Docs.summary: Optional boolean to indicate whether partial results should be returned by the recognizer as the user speaks (default is false).

remarks.para: Optional boolean to indicate whether partial results should be returned by the recognizer as the user speaks (default is false). The server may ignore a request for partial results in some or all cases.

Docs.summary: Optional text prompt to show to the user when asking them to speak.

remarks.para: Optional text prompt to show to the user when asking them to speak.

Docs.summary: An ArrayList<String> of the recognition results when performing .

remarks.para: An ArrayList<String> of the recognition results when performing . Generally this list should be ordered in descending order of speech recognizer confidence. (See ). Returned in the results; not to be specified in the recognition request. Only present when is returned in an activity result. In a PendingIntent, the lack of this extra indicates failure.

Docs.summary: When the intent is , the speech input activity will return results to you via the activity results mechanism.

remarks.para: When the intent is , the speech input activity will return results to you via the activity results mechanism. Alternatively, if you use this extra to supply a PendingIntent, the results will be added to its bundle and the PendingIntent will be sent to its target.

Docs.summary: If you use to supply a forwarding intent, you can also use this extra to supply additional extras for the final intent.

remarks.para: If you use to supply a forwarding intent, you can also use this extra to supply additional extras for the final intent. The search results will be added to this bundle, and the combined bundle will be sent to the target.

Docs.summary: Optional boolean to indicate that a "hands free" voice search was performed while the device was in a secure mode.

remarks.para:
Optional boolean to indicate that a "hands free" voice search was performed while the device was in a secure mode. An example of secure mode is when the device's screen lock is active, and it requires some form of authentication to be unlocked.
When the device is securely locked, the voice search activity should either restrict the set of voice actions that are permitted, or require some form of secure authentication before proceeding.

Docs.summary: The amount of time that it should take after we stop hearing speech to consider the input complete.

remarks.para:
The amount of time that it should take after we stop hearing speech to consider the input complete.
Note that it is extremely rare you'd want to specify this value in an intent. If you don't have a very good reason to change these, you should leave them as they are. Note also that certain values may cause undesired or unexpected results - use judiciously! Additionally, depending on the recognizer implementation, these values may have no effect.

Docs.summary: The minimum length of an utterance.

remarks.para:
The minimum length of an utterance. We will not stop recording before this amount of time.
Note that it is extremely rare you'd want to specify this value in an intent. If you don't have a very good reason to change these, you should leave them as they are. Note also that certain values may cause undesired or unexpected results - use judiciously! Additionally, depending on the recognizer implementation, these values may have no effect.

Docs.summary: The amount of time that it should take after we stop hearing speech to consider the input possibly complete.

remarks.para:
The amount of time that it should take after we stop hearing speech to consider the input possibly complete. This is used to prevent the endpointer cutting off during very short mid-speech pauses.
Note that it is extremely rare you'd want to specify this value in an intent. If you don't have a very good reason to change these, you should leave them as they are. Note also that certain values may cause undesired or unexpected results - use judiciously! Additionally, depending on the recognizer implementation, these values may have no effect.

Docs.summary: The key to the extra in the returned by which is an of s that represents the languages supported by this implementation of voice recognition - a list of strings like "en-US", "cmn-Hans-CN", etc.

remarks.para: The key to the extra in the returned by which is an of s that represents the languages supported by this implementation of voice recognition - a list of strings like "en-US", "cmn-Hans-CN", etc.

Docs.summary: Optional boolean, to be used with , to indicate whether to only fire web searches in response to a user's speech.

remarks.para: Optional boolean, to be used with , to indicate whether to only fire web searches in response to a user's speech. The default is false, meaning that other types of actions can be taken based on the user's speech.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig class Android.Content.Intent GetVoiceDetailsIntent(class Android.Content.Context context) cil managed

Docs.summary:
Returns the broadcast intent to fire with
to receive details from the package that implements voice search.

remarks.para:
Returns the broadcast intent to fire with
to receive details from the package that implements voice search.
This is based on the value specified by the voice search in , and if this is not specified, will return null. Also if there is no chosen default to resolve for , this will return null.
If an intent is returned and is fired, a of extras will be returned to the provided result receiver, and should ideally contain values for and .
(Whether these are actually provided is up to the particular implementation. It is recommended that s implementing provide this information, but it is not required.)

Docs.summary: Use a language model based on free-form speech recognition.

remarks.para: Use a language model based on free-form speech recognition. This is a value to use for .

Docs.summary: Use a language model based on web search terms.

remarks.para: Use a language model based on web search terms. This is a value to use for .

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which contains the java.lang.Class JNI value corresponding to this type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control which jclass is provided to methods like .

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which provides the declaring type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control virtual vs. non virtual method dispatch against the underlying JNI object. When this property is equal to the declaring type, then virtual method invocation against the JNI object is performed; otherwise, we assume that the method was overridden by a derived type, and perform non-virtual methdo invocation.
